nodes.text: Ergodicity economics (EE) as advanced by Peters and collaborators is pseudoscience because it has not produced falsifiable implications and meets multiple indicators of pseudoscience
Peters and collaborators claim mainstream economic theory is flawed and propose 'ergodicity economics' as a conceptually clearer alternative

Model setup for comparison: risky asset price follows geometric Brownian motion dS/S = mu dt + sigma dB, safe return r, investor chooses fixed leverage theta, wealth follows dW/W = (r + (mu-r)theta)dt + sigma theta dB

Log wealth is an arithmetic Brownian motion so log W_T is normal with mean (r + (mu-r)theta - 0.5 sigma^2 theta^2)T and variance sigma^2 theta^2 T, yielding closed form expressions for long-run geometric growth rate
EE prescription: maximize long-run geometric average growth rate which leads to optimal portfolio theta = (mu - r)/sigma^2
Expected utility theory (EUT) with CRRA utility yields objective V(theta)=r+(mu-r)theta - 0.5 gamma sigma^2 theta^2 and optimal portfolio theta = (mu - r)/(gamma sigma^2)
EE and EUT make identical portfolio predictions only in the special case of log utility, i.e., gamma = 1; otherwise predictions differ and EUT introduces an unobserved risk aversion parameter gamma

EE has not provided general, testable prescriptions for richer problems (e.g., multi-period consumption-investment with stochastic income), and authors have deferred such generalizations to future work

Publication and dissemination evidence: Peters lists many papers but relatively few in economics journals; of 34 listed, 22 published and only three are in journals remotely related to economics, many working papers and popular media dissemination

EE exhibits multiple indicators commonly associated with pseudoscience: vague or grandiose claims, improper or selective evidence, limited peer review in the economics community, slow substantive progress, personalization of critique, and ambiguous or misleading language
Indicator - vague or untestable claims: authors claim to 'resolve the fundamental problem of decision theory' without concrete applications or testable implications
Indicator - improper collection or use of evidence: empirical evidence cited (e.g., Meder et al.) has been criticized and some citations are used out of context
Indicator - lack of openness to testing by domain experts: EE work is rarely published in core economics journals and appears infrequently reviewed by economists

Indicator - absence of progress and misleading language: EE frequently cites old results (Kelly, Latan√©) and uses terms like 'indiscriminate assumption of ergodicity' without clear definition in economic contexts

Conclusion: Because EE currently lacks broad falsifiable implications and displays several indicators of pseudoscience, it should be treated with skepticism until it produces testable, peer-reviewed results in economics
